prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA post (the author) is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old to a fun activity while their partner is at work.

First, the context: The author mentions that almost every weekend they want to take their kid to a play center or farm, but their partner uses excuses like not wanting to go out, being tired, or not wanting to spend money. The author points out they have money, so it's not a real issue. Then, the author agreed to go to a farm with a friend, which the partner found out and got upset, saying it's unfair because he's at work. The author counters by saying they had asked before and were told no, so they thought it was okay to go on their own. The partner wants to cancel and go another day, but the author is fine with going whenever the partner wants.

So, the main question is whether the author is in the wrong. The key points here are about shared responsibilities in parenting and fairness in decision-making. The author's partner is making excuses for not participating in activities, but when the author takes initiative without them, the partner feels left out or that it's unfair. 

The author isn't doing anything harmful to the child. The activity is a petting zoo, which is appropriate and not like a movie date. The partner's reaction seems more about feeling excluded rather than the activity itself. The author is also trying to provide a fun experience for the child, which is a valid parent's role. 

The partner's excuses (not wanting to spend money, being tired) don't hold up since they have money and the cost is minimal. The author is taking responsibility for the child's enjoyment when the partner is unwilling. The partner's sudden objection when the author acts on their own might be about control or feeling left out, but the author isn't being selfish; they're fulfilling their role as a parent. 

In such cases, it's common for one parent to take the initiative when the other is uninterested. The author isn't excluding the partner from all future activities; they’re just going once. The partner is free to join later. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong.
